body:
Solution - dont modify scripts outside of ZAP ;)
I guess we could provide an option to resync, but out of interest, why are you modifying the scripts using another tool?

- Using your favorite text editor (vim, atom, ...)
- File is mounted (sshfs, smb, ...)
- File is externally auto generated (curl, ...)
- Run scripts on (sed, ...)
- ...

What is the path (if exist) of the current edited script inside ZAP ? so I can rsync manually for the moment.

Another question: How can one debug the script (breakpoint, single stepping, ...) outside ZAP when it is being called by ZAP ?

The scripts are put under the scripts/scripts directory in the ZAP directory, which by default is https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy/wiki/FAQconfig

I'm not aware of any way to debug a script running in ZAP from outside, I usually just add add print statements to show me whats going on ;)
If you find a standard way of debugging JSR223 scripts in Java then please let us know.

The 'scripts/scripts' does not reflect the current stat of file being edited in ZAP.
I current have no idea to debug JSR223.
How about live-debugging others (python, ...) ?

You need to Save the scripts before the filesystem will be updated.
All of the scripts we support (including python) we do via JSR223: https://www.jcp.org/en/jsr/detail?id=223
If that doesnt support debugging then it would probably be very difficult for us to implement it ourselves.

@thc202 pointed me to this thread when I had stumbled over needing to restart the ZAP daemon after modifying an auth script. In my case, the whole thing is automated: installation/configuration of ZAP by configuration management, installation/config/running the target by Jenkins et al., running the scan using orchestration tooling. So, during a debugging session, I modified the auth script and wondered (briefly) why the behaviour didn't change. Then I realised I needed to bounce ZAP and run my testing script (which loads the auth script) again. And all was well.
Does disabling/enabling the script have the same effect?
I'm afraid not (note that the authentication scripts can't be enabled/disabled).

I think there are 3 use cases here, and in each case a script has been edited outside of ZAP:

- The script is not in the script console tab, in which case we can just use the new one
- The script is in the console but hasnt been changed, in which case we should replace the one in the script console with the new one and use that
- The script is in the console and has been changed, in which case we should use the new one (we dont want to prevent httpsender etc sctipts from running) but should prompt user to see if they want to keep the one they've changed or use the new one

If the script it not in the console then we can just check for the file on disk having been changed based on the timestamp. If it is in the console then we might need to have a timer thread which keeps checking the filestore for changes?
Does that cover it?

I think so. Would it be better to checksum/hash the content instead of depending on modification timestamp? That would address changes and reversions (when new timestamp isn't new content), and might also provide a mechanism to address (https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy/issues/2189)?

I'd rather not have to checksum script files every time they run, that could impact performance. 
How useful will checksumming be? That would just be if someone touched the file on filestore but didnt change its contents? If we reload it then its no problem, and if its in the console and we prompt the user then they can just keep their current changes?
Will the user be able to enable/disable this? Or, is it enabled (by default?) for all scripts?

I was thinking it would be enabled by default and not configurable. But if anyone can suggest reasons why people might not want this then happy to make it an option...
I am planning on looking at this, but havnt assigned it to myself yet just in case I dont get round to it ;)

issue.title: Reload scripts if they have changed on disk

repository.name: zaproxy
repository.description: The ZAP by Checkmarx Core project

issue.body:
Fixes #2950
This will not play well with any scripts being displayed in the script console, so that will need to be changed as well. I'll raise another bug for that.

issue.title: Script Console should handle scripts changed on disk

repository.name: zaproxy
repository.description: The ZAP by Checkmarx Core project

issue.body:
Related to https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy/issues/2950
If https://github.com/zaproxy/zaproxy/pull/4449 is merged then the Script Console will need to change to handle scripts that have changed on disk.
The code also needs to handle scripts that have been changed but not saved - these might not be the currently displayed script.
The script currently being displayed should also be handled if its changed on disk even if its not been changed via the console,
In all cases the user should be prompted to ask if they want to change to see the new contents, and informed if any changes they made via the console will be lost.

body: This thread has been automatically locked since there has not been any recent activity after it was closed. Please open a new issue for related bugs.
